Βύλλις or Βουλλίς {{in lang|el}} |image=Qyteti Ilir I Bylisit 05.jpg |caption=Ruins of Old Bylis |map_type = Albania |map_alt = |map_size = 150 |location = [[Hekal]], [[Fier County]], Albania |region = [[Illyria]] |coordinates = {{coord|40.5403|19.7375|display=inline,title}} |type = Settlement |part_of = |length = |width = |area = |height = |builder = |material = |built = |abandoned = |epochs = Hellenistic, Roman, Byzantine |cultures = Illyrian, Greek, Roman, Byzantine |occupants = |event = |excavations = 1978–1991, 2000-present |archaeologists = [[Camillo Prashniker]], [[Neritan Çeka]], [[Skënder Muçaj]], [[Jean-Pierre Sodini]], [[Pascale Chevalier]], [[Nicolas Beaudry]] |condition = |ownership = Public |public_access = |website = |notes = |designation1=Cultural Monument of Albania |}} '''Byllis''' ({{lang-grc|Βύλλις}}) or '''Bullis''' or '''Boullis''' (Βουλλίς) was an ancient city located in the region of [[Illyria]]. The remains of Byllis are situated north-east of [[Vlorë]], 25 kilometers from the sea in [[Hekal]], [[Fier County]], [[Albania]]. [[Stephanus of Byzantium]] mentions Byllis as a seaside city (erroneously) in Illyria and its foundation legend, according to which the city was built by [[Myrmidons]] under [[Neoptolemus]], [[Nostos|returning from the Trojan War]], a tradition confirmed by numismatics.{{cite book|last=Ceka and Mucau|title=Byllis|year=2005|publisher=Migjeni|location=Tirana|isbn=99943-672-7-7|pages=11}} The city, although a Greek speaking settlement was located on the territory of the Illyrian tribe of [[Bylliones]]. The latter were first attested in the mid-4th century BC, in the description of the geographer Pseudo-Scylax,{{cite book|last=Pseudo-Scylax|title=Periplus, 27}} and also asking the oracle of [[Dodona]] to which god they should sacrifice in order to ensure the safety of their possessions. The archaeological attestation of the city is possible as far back as the second half of the 4th century BC and was later conquered by Pyrrhus.[https://books.google.com/books?ei=nGBzTYncDs644AbikcDRDQ&ct=result&id=d2cJAQAAIAAJ&dq=Byllis+%2B+Pyrrhus&q=Byllis+came+into+the+hands+of+Pyrrhus+following+the+conquest+of+Apollonia#search_anchor Pyrrhus King of Epirus] Petros Garouphalias According to another view, Byllis was founded by king [[Pyrrhus of Epirus]]. Byllis received [[theoroi|sacred Greek envoys]], known as theoroi during the early 2nd century BC, indicator of the city's [[Greeks|Greek]] character.[[Peter Allan Hansen]]. [https://books.google.com/books?ei=WldzTZGVGoOs8gPP96mvCA&ct=result&id=Zhs8AAAAMAAJ&dq=byllis%2Bgreek&q=%22from+which+it+appears+that+Byllis+was+a+Greek+city%2C%22#search_anchor Carmina epigraphica Graeca]. Novus Eboracus, 1983. {{ISBN|978-3-11-008387-3}}, p. 295. ==The city== Byllis, being a Greek-speaking city,Tom Winnifrith. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Tq4TAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Thus+Byllis,+the+largest+city+in+the+territory+of+the+Illyrian+Bylliones,+was+a+Greek-speaking+city,+visited+by+Greek+envoys+from+the+shrines+of+Greece%22&dq=%22Thus+Byllis,+the+largest+city+in+the+territory+of+the+Illyrian+Bylliones,+was+a+Greek-speaking+city,+visited+by+Greek+envoys+from+the+shrines+of+Greece%22&hl=el&ei=i0FzTavfFsek8QPHysmvCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA Perspectives on Albania]. Macmillan, 1992. {{ISBN|978-0-333-51282-1}}, p. 37 on the borders of Illyria and Epirus, had its own stadium and theatre during the Hellenistic era.Tom Winnifrith. [https://books.google.com/books?ei=I0JzTe-8IIqj8QOixMGvCA&ct=result&id=dkRoAAAAMAAJ&dq=byllis%2Bgreek&q=%22Later+Amantia+and+Byllis+acquired+the+trappings+of+a+Hellenistic+town.+Byllis+has+a+theatre+and+a+stadium%2C%22#search_anchor Badlands, borderlands: a history of Northern Epirus/Southern Albania]. Duckworth, 2002. {{ISBN|978-0-7156-3201-7}}, p. 58 About its foundation it has been suggested that Byllis was founded by Greek settlers,{{harvnb|Hammond|1989|page=19}} though the fact that it had a mixed population is attested by the Illyrian names of officials.{{harvnb|Ceka|Muçaj|2005}} The city had its own coinage which was different from that of the tribe of the Bylliones.{{harvnb|Hammond|1989|page=18}} M. B. Hatzopoulos believes that Byllis is the northernmost non-colonian Greek city in the region.M. B. Hatzopoulos. [https://books.google.com/books?ei=UC47TraTPMiYOqmx_KUC&ct=result&id=UV1oAAAAMAAJ&dq=%22The+above+review+suggests+that+the+northern+boundaries+of+Hellenism+in+Epirus+%22&q=%22the+northernmost+Greek+city+in+this+region+that+was+not+a+colonial+foundation%22#search_anchorr ''The Borders of Hellenism in Epirus during Antiquity'']. Epirus: Ekdotike Athenon, p. 145, 1997. The walls of Byllis were 2,200m long, enclosing 30 hectares of a plain atop a hill 524m above sea level. There were 6 gates in the city walls. The road coming from [[Apollonia, Illyria|Apollonia]] passed through two of them, crossing Byllis in the direction of the narrows of gorges of the [[Vjosa]] river on the way to [[Ancient Macedonia|Macedonia]] or those of [[Antigonia (Chaonia)|Antigonia]] in the direction of [[Epirus]]. In 2011 during a road reconstruction near the archaeological park found in the site a statue of the Hellenistic era, which may depict an Illyrian soldier or a war deity, was discovered.[http://www.balkanweb.com/kultur%C3%AB/2691/fier-zbulohet-statuja-antike-ne-bylis-57328.html Fier: Ancient statue discovered in Byllis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304115151/http://www.balkanweb.com/kultur%C3%AB/2691/fier-zbulohet-statuja-antike-ne-bylis-57328.html |date=2016-03-04 }} However, there is little point in proposing an Illyrian label for city in which language, institutions, officials, onomastics, city-planning and fortifications were Greek. [[File:Map of ancient Epirus and environs (English).svg|right|thumb|Epirus in antiquity.]] [[File:Byllis Vjosa.jpg|thumb|right|Image of the ancient site of Byllis and the river [[Vjosa]] in the distance.]] ==League of the Bylliones== The League ([[Koinon]]) of the [[Illyrians|Illyrian]] tribe of the Bylliones ([[Ancient Greek]]: Κοινὸν Βυλλίων), which had been [[Hellenization|hellenized]] to a degree and was bilingual,Marjeta Šašel Kos. [https://books.google.com/books?ei=e0BzTY2jCdCq8QPM2aCvCA&ct=result&id=opBpAAAAMAAJ&dq=bylliones+hellenized&q=%22No+doubt+various+southern+Illyrian+peoples+such+as+the+Atintanes%2C+Bylliones%2C+Taulantii%2C+Parthini%2C+Bryges%2C+and+others+acquired+a+certain+degree+of+Hellenization%2C+both+on+account+of+the+common+border+with+Epirus+and+the+nearness+of+Greek%22#search_anchor Appian and Illyricum]. Narodni muzej Slovenije, 2005, p. 226 was a coalition of one or two poleis,Pleket, H. W. ''Supplementum Epigraphicum Graecum'', Volume XXXIX: 1989. as attested after 232 BC.{{harvnb|Wilkes|1995|page=97}} The league was restricted to Byllis and [[Nikaia (Epirus)|Nikaea]],Robert, L. "Discours inaugaural", ''L' Illyrie méridionale et L'Épire dans l'Antiquité, Actes du colloque international de Clermont-Ferrand''. Clermont-Ferrand, 1984 , p. 14. and Byllis considered Nikaia as one of its [[deme]]s. Nikaia was a member of the league, as a 2nd-century BC inscription indicates.{{harvnb|Hansen|Nielsen|2004|page=346}} The only attestation of the city as [[polis]] is in the work of [[Stephanus of Byzantium]] in the 6th century.{{harvnb|Bowden|2003}} On the other hand, the citizens of Byllis were called Byllideis ({{lang-el|Βυλλιδεῖς}}).{{harvnb|Hammond|1989|page=17}} ==Roman and Byzantine rule== Under the [[Roman Empire]], Byllis became part of the [[Roman province|province]] of [[Epirus Nova]]. Its name often occurs at the time of the civil wars.''e.g.'', [[Cicero]], ''Phil.'' 11.11; [[Julius Caesar]] ''B.C.'' 3.40. ''et alii'' In the time of [[Pliny the Elder]], it was a Roman colony, and was called ''Colonia Bullidensis''.{{Cite Pliny|4.10.17}} Its territory is called '''Bylliake''' (Βυλλιακή) by [[Strabo]].{{Cite Strabo|vii. p.316}} The walls of Byllis carry more than four inscriptions with details regarding their construction by the engineer Victorinus, as ordered by [[Emperor Justinian I]] (483-565).{{harvnb|Bowden|2003}}.{{cite book|last=Ceka and Mucaj|title=Byllis|year=2005|publisher=Migjeni|isbn=99943-672-7-7|pages=108–109}} == Association with see of Apollonia == One of the participants in the [[Council of Ephesus]] in 431 was a Felix who signed once as Bishop of [[Apollonia (Illyria)|Apollonia]] and Byllis, at another time as Bishop of Apollonia. Some assume that the two towns formed a single episcopal see, others suppose he was, strictly speaking, Bishop only of Apollonia, but was temporarily in charge also of Byllis during a vacancy of that see. At the [[Council of Chalcedon]] in 451, Eusebius subscribes simply as Bishop of Apollonia. In the letter of the bishops of [[Epirus Nova]] to the Byzantine Emperor [[Leo I (emperor)|Leo I]] in 458, Philocharis subscribed as Bishop of what the manuscripts call "Vallidus", and which editors think should be corrected to "Byllis". Whether Philocharis is to be considered Bishop also of Apollonia depends on the interpretation of the position of Felix in 431.Daniele Farlati-Jacopo Coleti, ''Illyricum Sacrum'', vol. VII, Venezia 1817, [https://books.google.com/books?id=z1zLr_T1esUC&pg=PA395 pp. 395-396]Michel Lequien, [https://books.google.com/books?id=86weAemI-e4C&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Oriens christianus in quatuor Patriarchatus digestus''], Parigi 1740, Vol. II, coll. 248-249[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/03092e.htm Louis Petit, "Byllis" in ''Catholic Encyclopedia'' (New York 1908)] The ''[[Annuario Pontificio]]'' lists Apollonia as a [[titular see]], thus recognizing that it was once a residential [[diocese]], a [[suffragan]] of the archbishopric of [[Dyrrachium]].''Annuario Pontificio 2013'' (Libreria Editrice Vaticana 2013 {{ISBN|978-88-209-9070-1}}), p. 835 It grants no such recognition to Byllis.''Annuario Pontificio 2013'' (Libreria Editrice Vaticana 2013 {{ISBN|978-88-209-9070-1}}), "Sedi titolari", pp. 819-1013 ==See also== *[[List of ancient Cities in Illyria]] *[[Tourism in Albania]] ==References== ===Citations=== {{Reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} * Beaudry, Nicolas (2010).
